contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox Anatomy | Name = Gonadotropic cell | Latin = | GraySubject = | GrayPage = | Image = | Caption = | Image2 = | Caption2 = | Precursor = | System = | Artery = | Vein = | Nerve = | Lymph = | MeshName = | MeshNumber = | Code = {{TerminologiaHistologica|3|08|02.2.00004}} | }} '''Gonadotropes''' are [[endocrine]] [[cell (biology)|cells]] in the [[anterior pituitary]] that produce the [[gonadotropins]], such as the [[follicle-stimulating hormone]] (FSH) and [[luteinizing hormone]] (LH). Release of FSH and LH by gonadotrophs is regulated by [[gonadotropin-releasing hormone]] (GnRH) from the [[hypothalamus]].<ref>Ganong, William F.: "Review of Medical Physiology", page 248. Lange, 2005.</ref> Gonadotropes appear [[basophilic]] in histological preparations. Gonadotropes have insulin receptors, which can be overstimulated by too high insulin levels. This may lead to infertility as hormone release levels are disrupted. <ref name=Brot2010>{{cite doi|10.1016/j.cmet.2010.06.010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | author=Hill JW, Elias CF, Fukuda M, Williams KW, Berglund ED, Holland WL, Cho YR, Chuang JC, Xu Y, Choi M, Lauzon D, Lee CE, Coppari R, Richardson JA, Zigman JM, Chua S, Scherer PE, Lowell BB, Brüning JC, Elmquist JK. | title = Direct insulin and leptin action on pro-opiomelanocortin neurons is required for normal glucose homeostasis and fertility. | journal = Cell Metabolism | volume = 11 | issue = 4 | pages = 286–97 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20374961 | pmc =2854520 }}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} {{Endocrine system anatomy}} {{Human cell types derived primarily from ectoderm}} [[Category:Peptide hormone secreting cells]] [[Category:Human cells]] {{Cell-biology-stub}}
